Employees API#

This page highlights the different endpoints that are available to the web interface to interact with employee data.

Usage#

GET /api/v1/employees/count#

An endpoint that counts the number of employees registered in the database and returns it in the response.

Status Codes

  • 200 OK – When the total number of employees is successfully retrieved from the database.

Example request:

GET /api/v1/employees/count HTTP/1.1

Headers:
{
    "Authorization": "Bearer <access_token>"
}

Example response:

HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Content-Type: application/json

{
    "status": 200,
    "message": "success",
    "data": {
        "count": 1
    }
}
GET /api/v1/employees/all#

An endpoint that retrieves all the employees from the database and formats it into a list.

Status Codes

  • 200 OK – When the list of employees is successfully retrieved from the database.

Example request:

GET /api/v1/employees/all HTTP/1.1

Headers:
{
    "Authorization": "Bearer <access_token>"
}

Example response:

HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Content-Type: application/json

{
    "status": 200,
    "message": "success",
    "data": {
        "employees": [
            {
                "employee_id": "jsmith300",
                "first_name": "John",
                "last_name": "Smith",
                "is_enabled": true
            },
            {
                "employee_id": jsmith301",
                "first_name": "Johnny",
                "last_name": "Smith",
                "is_enabled": false
            }
        ]
    }
}
GET /api/v1/employees#

An endpoint that retrieves multiple specific employees from the database and formats it into a list.

Parameters

  • employee_ids – A list of employee IDs to retrieve employees from the database.

Status Codes

  • 200 OK – When the list of employees is successfully retrieved from the database.

Example request:

GET /api/v1/employees HTTP/1.1

Headers:
{
    "Authorization": "Bearer <access_token>"
}
Body:
{
    "employee_ids": ["jsmith300", "jsmith301"]
}

Example response:

HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Content-Type: application/json

{
    "status": 200,
    "message": "success",
    "data": {
        "employees": [
            {
                "employee_id": "jsmith300",
                "first_name": "John",
                "last_name": "Smith",
                "is_enabled": true
            },
            {
                "employee_id": jsmith301",
                "first_name": "Johnny",
                "last_name": "Smith",
                "is_enabled": false
            }
            ......
        ]
    }
}
GET /api/v1/employees/:{employee_id}:#

An endpoint that retrieves detailed employee information from the database by providing the ID in the URL.

Status Codes

  • 200 OK – When the detailed employee information is successfully retrieved from the database.

Example request:

GET /api/v1/employees/:{employee_id}: HTTP/1.1

URL: <server_url>/api/v1/employees/jsmith317
Headers:
{
    "Authorization": "Bearer <access_token>"
}

Example response:

HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Content-Type: application/json

{
    "status": 200,
    "message": "success",
    "data": {
        "employee": {
            "employee_id": "jsmith317",
            "first_name": "john",
            "last_name": "smith",
            "role": "employee",
            "full_name_of_contact": "john smith",
            "primary_email": "johnsmith123@email.com",
            "secondary_email": null,
            "enable_notifications": true,
            "is_enabled": true
        }
    }
}
GET /api/v1/employees/token#

An endpoint that retrieves basic employee information such as the employee ID, first name, last name, and status from the access token.

Status Codes

  • 200 OK – When the employee is successfully retrieved from the database.

Example request:

GET /api/v1/employees/token HTTP/1.1

Headers:
{
    "Authorization": "Bearer <access_token>"
}

Example response:

HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Content-Type: application/json

{
    "status": 200,
    "message": "success",
    "data": {
        "employees": {
            "employee_id": "jsmith317",
            "first_name": "john",
            "last_name": "smith",
            "role": "employee",
            "full_name_of_contact": "john smith",
            "primary_email": "johnsmith123@email.com",
            "secondary_email": null,
            "enable_notifications": true,
            "is_enabled": true
        }
    }
}
POST /api/v1/employees#

An endpoint to create a new employee entity and adds it to the employees’ table in the database.

Parameters

  • first_name – The first name of the new employee.

  • last_name – The last name of the new employee.

  • plain_password – The plain-text password for the next employee account.

  • primary_email – The primary email contact for the employee.

  • [Optional] (is_enabled) – The secondary email contact for the employee.

  • [Optional] – Enable or disable email notifications, enabled by default.

  • [Optional] – Enable or disable the new account, enabled by default.

Status Codes

  • 201 Created – When the employee is successfully created and registered in the database.

  • 400 Bad Request – When the request body contains invalid parameters, or the employee already exists in the database.

Example request:

POST /api/v1/employees/new HTTP/1.1
Headers:
{
    "Authorization": "Bearer <access_token>"
}
Body:
{
    "first_name": "John",
    "last_name": "Smith",
    "plain_password": "john123",
    "role": "employee"
    "primary_email": "johnsmith123@email.com",
    [OPTIONAL] "secondary_email": null,
    [OPTIONAL] "enable_notifications": true,
    [OPTIONAL] "is_enabled": true
}

Example response:

HTTP/1.1 201 OK
Content-Type: application/json

{
    "status": 201,
    "message": "success",
    "data": {
        "employee": {
            "employee_id": "jsmith318",
            "first_name": "john",
            "last_name": "smith",
            "role_name": "employee",
            "primary_email": "johnsmith123@email.com",
            "secondary_email": null,
            "email_notifications_enabled": true,
            "is_enabled": true
        }
    }
}
DELETE /api/v1/employees#

An endpoint to delete an existing employee record from the database.

Parameters

  • employee_ids – The employee IDs of the employees to be removed provided as a list. If only one employee needs to be deleted, it can be provided as a string.

Status Codes

  • 201 Created – When the employee is successfully deleted from the database.

  • 400 Bad Request – When the request body contains invalid parameters, or the employee does not exist in the database.

Example request:

DELETE /api/v1/employees HTTP/1.1
Headers:
{
    "Authorization": "Bearer <access_token>"
}
Body:
{
    "employee_ids": "jsmith300"
    [OR]
    "employee_ids": ["jsmith300", "jsmith301", "jsmith302"]
}

Example response:

HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Content-Type: application/json

{
    "status": 200,
    "message": "success",
    "data": {
        "employee": {
            "employee_id": "jsmith300",
            "first_name": "John",
            "last_name": "Smith",
            "is_enabled": true,
            "entry_created": "2022-03-01T09:46:58"
        }
    }
}

Implementation Documentation#

This module consists of FastAPI routing for Employees. This handles all the REST API logic for creating, reading, updating, and destroying employee-related data.

class server.web_api.routing.v1.employee_routing.EmployeesRouter#

Bases: object

class Create#

Bases: object

async static register_new_employee(pyd_employee: server.lib.data_classes.employee.PydanticEmployeeRegistration, token: str = Depends(OAuth2PasswordBearer), session=Depends(get_db_session))#

An endpoint to create a new employee entity and adds it to the employees’ table in the database.

Parameters

  • pyd_employee (PydanticEmployeeRegistration, required) – The Pydantic Employee Registration reference. This means that HTTP requests to this endpoint must include the required fields in the PydanticEmployeeRegistration.

  • token (str, required) – The JSON Web Token responsible for authenticating the user to this endpoint.

  • session (sqlalchemy.orm.Session, optional) – The database session to use to register a new employee.

Returns

A response model containing the employee object that was created from the provided information with a generated employee ID and hashed password.

Return type

server.web_api.models.ResponseModel

Raises

HTTPException – If the provided request body contains any invalid parameters for the employee. This error may also be caused if the employee already exists in the database.

class Delete#

Bases: object

async static delete_all_employees(are_you_sure: str, token: str = Depends(OAuth2PasswordBearer), session=Depends(get_db_session))#

An endpoint to remove ALL employee records from the employee’s table in the database. Removal of multiple employees using this endpoint will permanently delete the employee records from the database and all records related to the employee records in other tables through a cascading delete.

Parameters

  • are_you_sure (str, required) – An additional parameter that must say ‘yes’ to fulfill this request, to prevent accidental deletion.

  • token (str, required) – The JSON Web Token responsible for authenticating the user to this endpoint.

  • session (sqlalchemy.orm.session, optional) – The database session to use to delete the employee records.

Returns

A response model containing the number of employees deleted.

Return type

server.web_api.models.ResponseModel

Raises

HTTPException – If the provided request body contains invalid parameters.

async static delete_employee(employee_id: str, token: str = Depends(OAuth2PasswordBearer), session=Depends(get_db_session))#

An endpoint to remove an employee record from the employee’s table in the database. Removal of an employee using this endpoint will permanently delete the employee record from the database and all records related to the employee record in other tables through a cascading delete.

Parameters

  • employee_id (str, required) – The ID of the employee that needs to be deleted.

  • token (str, required) – The JSON Web Token responsible for authenticating the user to this endpoint.

  • session (sqlalchemy.orm.session, optional) – The database session to use to delete the employee record.

Returns

A response model containing the employee object that was deleted from the database.

Return type

server.web_api.models.ResponseModel

Raises

HTTPException – If the provided request body contains an invalid employee ID, or if the employee does not exist in the database.

async static delete_employees(employee_ids: server.lib.data_classes.employee.PydanticEmployeesRemoval, token: str = Depends(OAuth2PasswordBearer), session=Depends(get_db_session))#

An endpoint to remove multiple employee records from the employee’s table in the database. Removal of multiple employees using this endpoint will permanently delete the employee records from the database and all records related to the employee records in other tables through a cascading delete. To remove multiple employee records, the employee IDs must be provided in a list.

Parameters

  • employee_ids (PydanticEmployeeRemoval, required) – A list of IDs of employees that needs to be deleted.

  • token (str, required) – The JSON Web Token responsible for authenticating the user to this endpoint.

  • session (sqlalchemy.orm.session, optional) – The database session to use to delete the employee record.

Returns

A response model containing the employee object that was deleted from the database.

Return type

server.web_api.models.ResponseModel

Raises

HTTPException – If the provided request body contains an invalid employee ID, or if the employee does not exist in the database.

class Read#

Bases: object

async static read_all_employees(token: str = Depends(OAuth2PasswordBearer), session=Depends(get_db_session))#

An endpoint that retrieves all the employees from the database and formats it into a list.

Parameters

  • token (str, required) – The JSON Web Token responsible for authenticating the user to this endpoint.

  • session (sqlalchemy.orm.session, optional) – The database session to use to retrieve all the employee data.

Returns

List of all employees found in the database with the total count of employees. If there are no employees in the database, an empty list and a count of 0 is returned.

Return type

server.web_api.models.ResponseModel

Raises

HTTPException – If the authentication token is invalid.

async static read_employee_from_token(token: str = Depends(OAuth2PasswordBearer), session=Depends(get_db_session))#

An endpoint that retrieves the employee from the database that matches a provided valid access token.

Parameters

  • token (str, required) – The JSON Web Token responsible for authenticating the user to this endpoint and to use to retrieve the employee.

  • session (sqlalchemy.orm.session, optional) – The database session to use to retrieve the employee data.

Returns

The employee found in the database that matches the provided access token. If there are no matching employees, an error is shown.

Return type

server.web_api.models.ResponseModel

Raises

HTTPException – If the authentication token is invalid or the employee does not exist.

async static read_employees_count(token: str = Depends(OAuth2PasswordBearer), session=Depends(get_db_session))#

An endpoint that counts the number of employees that are registered in the database.

Parameters

  • token (str, required) – The JSON Web Token responsible for authenticating the user to this endpoint.

  • session (sqlalchemy.orm.session, optional) – The database session to use to retrieve all the employee data.

Returns

A response model containing the number of employees found in the database.

Return type

server.web_api.models.ResponseModel

Raises

HTTPException – If the authentication token is invalid.

async static read_multiple_employees(employee_ids: server.lib.data_classes.employee.PydanticRetrieveMultipleEmployees, token: str = Depends(OAuth2PasswordBearer), session=Depends(get_db_session))#

An endpoint that retrieves a single employee from the database from the given employee ID

Parameters

  • employee_ids (str, required) – The list of employee IDs.

  • token (str, required) – The JSON Web Token responsible for authenticating the user to this endpoint.

  • session (sqlalchemy.orm.session, optional) – The database session to use to retrieve the employee data.

Returns

The employees found in the database.

Return type

server.web_api.models.ResponseModel

Raises

HTTPException – If the authentication token is invalid, the provided request data is invalid, or one or more of the employees does not exist.

async static read_one_employee(employee_id: str, token: str = Depends(OAuth2PasswordBearer), session=Depends(get_db_session))#

An endpoint that retrieves a single employee from the database from the given employee ID

Parameters

  • employee_id (str, required) – The ID of the employee.

  • token (str, required) – The JSON Web Token responsible for authenticating the user to this endpoint.

  • session (sqlalchemy.orm.session, optional) – The database session to use to retrieve the employee data.

Returns

The employees found in the database.

Return type

server.web_api.models.ResponseModel

Raises

HTTPException – If the authentication token is invalid or the employee could not be retrieved.

class Update#

Bases: object

async static update_employee_password(new_password: server.lib.data_classes.employee.PydanticUpdatePassword, token: str = Depends(OAuth2PasswordBearer), session=Depends(get_db_session))#

An endpoint that updates a single employee’s password from the database from the provided employee information and employee ID.

Parameters

  • new_password (str, required) – The new password for the employee.

  • token (str, required) – The JSON Web Token responsible for authenticating the user to this endpoint.

  • session (sqlalchemy.orm.session, optional) – The database session to use to update the employee data.

Returns

A response model containing the employee updated in the database.

Return type

server.web_api.models.ResponseModel

Raises

HTTPException – If the authentication token is invalid or the employee could not be updated.

async static update_multiple_employees(multi_employee_update: server.lib.data_classes.employee.PydanticMultipleEmployeesUpdate, token: str = Depends(OAuth2PasswordBearer), session=Depends(get_db_session))#

An endpoint that updates a single employee from the database from the provided employee information and employee ID.

Parameters

  • multi_employee_update (PydanticMultipleEmployeesUpdate, required) – A dictionary that consists of pairs of employee IDs and update information as per the PydanticEmployeeUpdate parameters.

  • token (str, required) – The JSON Web Token responsible for authenticating the user to this endpoint.

  • session (sqlalchemy.orm.session, optional) – The database session to use to update the employee data.

Returns

A response model containing the employee updated in the database.

Return type

server.web_api.models.ResponseModel

Raises

HTTPException – If the authentication token is invalid or the employees could not be updated.

async static update_one_employee(employee_id: str, employee_update: server.lib.data_classes.employee.PydanticEmployeeUpdate, token: str = Depends(OAuth2PasswordBearer), session=Depends(get_db_session))#

An endpoint that updates a single employee from the database from the provided employee information and employee ID.

Parameters

  • employee_id (str, required) – The ID of the employee.

  • employee_update (PydanticEmployeeUpdate, required) – The ID of the employee and any other employee information that needs to be updated.

  • token (str, required) – The JSON Web Token responsible for authenticating the user to this endpoint.

  • session (sqlalchemy.orm.session, optional) – The database session to use to update the employee data.

Returns

A response model containing the employee updated in the database.

Return type

server.web_api.models.ResponseModel

Raises

HTTPException – If the authentication token is invalid or the employee could not be updated.
